questions.question: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the followingimage. What is the probable diagnosis?
An infant with Edward's syndrome presents with the following radiological finding. Which ofthe following is false about this condition?414R

options.B: Mostly presents as vomiting within 1 week
options.C: Erythromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life can lead to this condition
options.D: Palpation of the pyloric olive is pathognomonic for this condition

questions.explanation: The radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) issuggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). It most commonly presents withnon-bilious projectile vomiting between 2-8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks.Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of thegastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:• Turner syndrome•• Edwards syndrome426•Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother'smilk.Palpation of the olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium is considered pathognomonic.USG criteria for diagnosing hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mmor a pyloric length >15-18 mm in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction isdiagnostic.

questions.question: An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen

options.C: During palpation over the left hypochondrium

questions.explanation: In a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), the abdominal mass is best seenduring test feed in the right upper quadrant.Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It iscommon between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resultsin constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.Clinically, when the infant is given a test feed, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upperquadrant and visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolicabnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results inloss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+)and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).All infants with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis are evaluated with an ultrasound(investigation of choice). It confirms the diagnosis in the majority of cases.Management: Rehydration and metabolic correction prior to definitive surgery - Ramstedt'spyloromyotomy.

questions.question: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which amongfollowing statements is true regarding her condition?
questions.explanation: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-biliousprojectile vomiting. It is common between 2-8 weeks of age.When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left toright, followed by projectile vomiting.Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.ehypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the developmentof metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys tryto compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulatesthe secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption ofsodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the developmentof hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It iscalled paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of427compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of CHPS seen on ultrasonography:•• Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipplesign.•The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervixand is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.The given ultrasound image shows thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign.Cervix sign- Nipple signPOST2 MIN FEEDTreatment:• The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to becorrected preoperatively.• The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

questions.question: Which part of the GIT is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult?
questions.explanation: Tonometry studies have shown that of all the parts of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT), the stomachis most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult and is also the slowest to recover.This may explain the high incidence of stress ulceration in the stomach.The Griffiths point (or Griffiths critical point) refers to the site of watershed anastomosis betweenthe ascending left colic artery and the marginal artery of Drummond occurring in the region of thesplenic flexure. Most anatomy texts describe its location as two-thirds along the transverse colon.The Sudeck point (or Sudeck critical point) refers to a specific location in the arterial supply of therectosigmoid junction, namely the origin of the last sigmoid arterial branch from the inferiormesenteric artery (IMA).428

questions.question: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic, with a history of binge drinking and multiple episodes ofvomiting, presents with hematemesis. On endoscopy, a longitudinal mucosal tear is found inthe gastroesophageal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mallory Weiss tear. It is due to a longitudinal tear inmucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction.It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, orstraining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice isendoscopy.Management of Mallory Weiss tear• Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting.• Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy.• Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails..• High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail.Boerhaave syndrome is characterized by spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. Here all layersare involved. Clinical features include Mackler's triad•Retching•Chest pain• Subcutaneous emphysemaGastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by dilated venules in the submucosa ofthe antrum.On endoscopy: Watermelon stomach.430DAILYROUNDSManagement of GAVEEndoscopic argon photocoagulation (APC)•If persistent - antrectomy.Dieulafoy lesion is a vascular malformation (dilated submucosal arterioles) that is seen along thelesser curvature of the stomach. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.Management of Dieulafoy lesion:• Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy•Angiographic embolization.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of increasing heartburn anddyspepsia for the past several months. He was prescribed PPIs for one month but he has norelief. You perform a urea breath test which is found to be positive. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: 431The given clinical scenario and the positive urea breath test are suggestive of a Helicobacter pyloriinfection which is most commonly associated with Type B gastritis.Type B gastritis usually affects the antrum. Intestinal metaplasia associated with chronicpan-gastritis and atrophy is seen. It has greater potential for malignancy as compared to Type Agastritis.Type A gastritis affects the fundus with antral sparing. Its features can be easily remembered by 4'A's:• Autoimmune condition - has circulating antibodies to parietal cells•Atrophy of parietal cell mass• Achlorhydria - causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like(ECL) cells•• Anemia - leads to pernicious anemia, due to malabsorption of Vit B12 (as the intrinsic factor isalso produced by parietal cells)

questions.question: Which of the following causes gastritis in patients with AIDS?
questions.explanation: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) gastritis is secondary to infection withcryptosporidiosis.•Other specific types of gastritis:Eosinophilic gastritis appears to have an allergic basis and is treated with steroids andcromoglycate.• Granulomatous gastritis is seen rarely in Crohn's disease and also may be associated withtuberculosis.• Phlegmonous gastritis is a rare bacterial infection of the stomach, found in patients with severeintercurrent illnesses.

questions.question: What is the most common site of gastric ulcer?
questions.explanation: The most common site of gastric ulcer is the lesser curvature near incisura.Approximately 60% of ulcers are in this location and are classified as type I gastric ulcers.These ulcers are generally not associated with excessive acid secretion and may occur with low tonormal acid output.

questions.question: Which type of gastric ulcer has increased gastric acid levels?
questions.explanation: Gastric ulcers of Types II (gastric body with duodenal ulcer) and III (prepyloric) are associatedwith increased gastric acid levels.432

questions.question: A biopsy was obtained from a patient with chronic peptic ulcer disease. The pathological slideis given below. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent of this condition.

options.B: Causes the most common type of gastritis
options.C: Associated with causation of gastric MALToma
options.D: Considered by WHO as class I carcinogen

questions.explanation: The given slide shows the GI mucosa, stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, infected withHelicobacter pylori. H. pylori cause hypergastrinemia.The ammonia released by H. pylori acts on the antral G-cells and releases gastrin. This isresponsible for hypergastrinemia in these patients resulting in type B gastritis (the most commontype of gastritis).Urea breath test and antibodies to H. pylori help us with diagnosis. The gold standardinvestigation for H. pylori is a tissue biopsy.H. pylori is classified by the WHO as a class I carcinogen because of the production of certaincytotoxins, notably the Cag A and Vac A, which are implicated in gastritis, peptic ulceration, andcancer.

questions.question: What is the most common complication that you expect in patients suffering from pepticulcer disease?
questions.explanation: The most common complication of peptic ulcer disease is bleeding, followed by perforation andobstruction.The most common site for perforation of peptic ulcers is the first part of the duodenum.Complications of peptic ulcers are•Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer.• Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer.• Obstruction•⚫ Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis.fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows doublepouched stomach.• Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lessercurvature.• An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver.• Malignancy.

questions.question: Which of the following is used for the classification of the endoscopic appearance of bleedingpeptic ulcers in a patient with peptic ulcer disease?
questions.explanation: Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. Itstratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent hemorrhage.Forrest classification is clinically very significant as it provides prognostic information to thesurgeon about the need for endoscopic therapeutic intervention and the risk of rebleeding.433Option B: The Glasgow-Blatchford bleeding score (GBS) is a screening tool to assess thelikelihood that a patient with acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) will need medicalintervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention. It incorporates the patient'sblood urea level, hemoglobin level, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters.Option C: Rockall score assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients withan upper GI bleed.Option D: The Bismuth-Corlette classification system provides an anatomic description of thetumor location and longitudinal extension in the biliary tree.Stigmata of Recent Hemorrh Forrest ClassificationageActive SpurtingI AActive OozingI BNon-bleeding vesselII AAdherent ClotII BFlat Pigmented SpotII CClean Based UlcerIII

questions.explanation: The most common vessel responsible for bleeding in peptic ulcer disease is the gastroduodenalartery. questions.question: A 23-year-old woman was admitted to the burns ward with an involvement of 45% of thebody surface area. She is at an increased risk of developing ulcers in which of the followingparts of the stomach?
questions.explanation: Left gastric arteryAortaCoeliac trunkOMARROWShort gastric arteriesLeft gastroepiploicartery- Splenic arteryRight gastroepiploic artery434A patient with burn is at risk of developing Curling's ulcers (stress ulcers). Stress ulcers in thestomach are located most commonly in the fundus.Stress gastritis occurs after a physical trauma, shock, sepsis, hemorrhage, or respiratory failure. Itis characterized by multiple superficial (non-ulcerating) erosions that begin in the proximal oracid-secreting portion of the stomach and progress distally. They are almost always seen in thefundus of the stomach and usually develop within 1 to 2 days after a traumatic event.The stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction causes systemic hypotension and reduced bloodflow leading to mucosal injury.On microscopic examination, they appear as wedge-shaped mucosal hemorrhages, withcoagulation necrosis of the superficial mucosal cells. Stress ulcers present as painless upper GIbleeds.Note: Cushing ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach,duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation. They occur due to gastricacid hypersecretion from direct vagal nerve stimulation.

questions.question: A 25-year-old man on SSRI presented with hematemesis and abdominal pain. An endoscopywas performed immediately which showed an actively bleeding ulcer of size 2cm in theposterior wall of the duodenum. What is the next best step in the management of thispatient?
questions.explanation: The next best step to manage the above scenario is endoscopic electrocoagulation.Management of bleeding peptic ulcer•For actively bleeding ulcers or non-bleeding visible vessels,Endoscopic therapy with a combination of epinephrine injection and electrocoagulation is done.Surgery is done only when 2 attempts of endoscopic therapy fail.●Surgical management includes duodenostomy and under-running of the vessel. Duodenal ulcersalso show a good response to acid-reducing surgery or vagotomy.Medical management includes PPIs and H.pylori eradication therapy.

questions.question: Which of the following is the preferred approach for treating a patient who has a duodenalulcer with a perforation of 2.5cm?

options.A: Primary closure and buttress with well-vascularised omentum

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain. Guarding is present onper abdomen examination. HR is 110bpm and BP is 88/60mmHg. Erect abdominal X-ray isshown below. Which of the following would you proceed with, for managing this case?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and erect X-ray abdomen showing gas under the diaphragm(pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of gastrointestinal perforation. It is managed by initialresuscitation with IV fluids followed by exploratory laparotomy. It is a surgical emergency.Management includes:• Adequate preoperative resuscitation with intravenous fluids followed by correction of electrolyteimbalance, instituting broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and●Early surgical intervention/laparotomy to address the cause for pneumoperitoneum and stopfurther contamination of the peritoneal cavity.

questions.question: A 54-year-old man presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting.Examination revealed tenderness over the right iliac fossa. USG showed gas around the rightkidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pneumoretroperitoneum caused by a perforatedduodenal ulcer.Posterior duodenal ulcer perforates into the retroperitoneum, and the contents leak through theright paracolic gutter into the right iliac fossa, mimicking appendicitis. This is called Valentinosyndrome.On USG, gas can be seen around the right kidney known as the renal veil sign.

questions.question: A 30-year-old actress who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity, presentswith complaints of sweating, palpitations, epigastric fullness, and loose stools which startimmediately after meals. Which of the following would you not associate with her condition?

options.A: It is precipitated by carbohydrate rich food.
options.B: It is more common after partial gastrectomy with the Billroth II reconstruction.
options.D: It is relieved by lying down.

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia does not occur inearly dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia is seen in late dumping syndrome secondary to raisedinsulin levels.Dumping syndrome is a complication occurring post gastrectomy. It can be early or late.Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading tosequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). This fluid shiftinduces autonomic responses. It is characterized by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects suchas:•Epigastric fullness• Sweating• Lightheadedness• Tachycardia• DiarrheaSymptoms are aggravated by having more food and relieved by lying down.439Late dumping syndrome is due to an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia. Thishypoglycemia causes a catecholamine surge, which results in predominantly cardiovascular effectssuch as:•• DiaphoresisTremulousness• Light-headedness• Tachycardia• ConfusionThe symptoms are aggravated by exercise and relieved by having food.The principal treatment for both types of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. Meals basedon fat and protein are known to work the best. Octreotide before meals is useful.

options.B: Organoaxial type is associated with a diaphragmatic defect
options.C: Surgery is performed through a transabdominal approach

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastric volvulus. Organoaxial gastric volvulus is morecommon (66%) than mesenteroaxial volvulus (33%).Organoaxial gastric volvulus: Torsion occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach and oftenoccurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus: Torsion occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.Organoaxialvolvulus(Longitudinal)GMARROWThe Borchardt triad is seen in gastric volvulus:• Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain• Recurrent retching with production of little vomitusInability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tubeMesenteroaxialvolvulus(Vertical)440Management involves reduction and uncoiling of the stomach through a transabdominalapproach.

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, lossof appetite, and loss of weight. On examination, the patient had peripheral edema and ascites.Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels oftransaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance of thestomach. Which of the following is true about the condition?423

options.B: Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases
options.C: Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosalfolds are characteristic of Menetrier's disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severecases of Menetrier's disease.Menetrier's disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused byoverexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), whichstimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolarhyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, andhypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared.There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia.Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cysticallydilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitory antibody, is now considered the first-line treatment forMenetrier's disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantialprotein loss refractory to cetuximab.441
